item.title: Attack Reported on Mali Hotel Used by European Union Military
item.description: The European Union’s military mission said in a Twitter post that its headquarters in Bamako had been assaulted. It reported no casualties.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Editorial: The Kurds’ Push for Self-Rule in Syria
item.description: A proposal for a semiautonomous region in Syria might be an idea worth building on.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Syrian Kurds from Kobani behind a border fence.

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Government Budget Will Seek Significant Increase in Deficit Spending
item.description: Canada’s new Liberal government will try to revive a flagging economy with one of the country’s biggest deficits since the 2008 financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: U.N. Warns of Election Violence
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged the Security Council to help United Nations peacekeepers preserve political stability in Congo.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘War of the Worlds’ Shape-Shifts Onto the London Stage
item.description: This stage production, whose team includes the album’s writer, cranks up the excess of “Jeff Wayne’s Musical Version of the War of the Worlds.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA
item.media:description: From left, Jimmy Nail, Heidi Range and Michael Praed in “The War of the Worlds,” which has been adapted for the West End stage in London.

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: State Dept. Says Persecution of Muslims Does Not Rise to Genocide
item.description: In a report to Congress seen, the department said it was “gravely concerned” about abuses against the Rohingya, but it did not constitute genocide.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: The Arrest of Salah Abdeslam, a Paris Suspect, Ends Manhunt, Not Questions
item.description: The arrest of Mr. Abdeslam, a suspect in the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks, highlights the challenges authorities face in the insular Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Police officers in the Molenbeek district of Brussels on Friday as they closed in on Salah Abdeslam, one of 10 suspects in the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris and the last one who is still alive.

item.title: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Vow to Protect Israel but Differ on Means
item.description: The candidates previewed for an influential pro-Israel audience a debate on foreign policy that could play out this fall if they face each other in the general election.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MAGGIE HABERMAN
item.media:description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio addressing the Aipac conference at the Verizon Center.

item.title: Morocco Asks That U.N. Close Western Sahara Military Office
item.description: The request was an indication that an escalating dispute between the Moroccan authorities and Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon over the disputed territory is not abating.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Reaction to Obama Trip Reflects Change in Cuban-Americans
item.description: Some in the Miami region retain the traditional resentment of the Castro government, but many more welcome the president’s visit as an opportunity.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ

item.title: Deal Appears to Curb Migrant Flow, but Greece Still Faces ‘Uphill Effort’
item.description: Some 48 hours after the European Union reached a refugee deal with Turkey, Greek officials confronted widespread confusion about how to handle refugees.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers directed a raft carrying migrants to the Greek island of Lesbos on Sunday. Officials said fewer arrived Monday.

item.title: Cuba Meeting Between Obama and Castro Exposes Old Grievances
item.description: During an extraordinary news conference, the leaders’ exchanges underscored how far the two nations have to travel to fully restore relations.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Cubans crowded the streets of Havana on Sunday to try to catch a glimpse of President Obama and his family.

item.title: Russian Judge Postpones Verdict in Trial of Ukrainian Pilot
item.description: Nadiya V. Savchenko is accused of directing artillery fire that killed two Russian journalists, in a case that has become symbolic in Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Stay or Go? Cuban Entrepreneurs Divided on Where to Stake Futures
item.description: While many leave for the United States, business owners opting to remain are creating an expanding class, optimistic despite serious challenges.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antonio, center background, and Sandra Camacho Rodríguez, to his right, named their bakery in Havana the Burner Brothers, a reference to all the cookies they burned on their way to opening the shop.

item.title: Anker Jorgensen, Former Prime Minister of Denmark, Dies at 93
item.description: He was a trade union leader with no government experience before leading Danish governments in the 1970s, and was known for his humble demeanor and opposition to the Vietnam War.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Belgian Police Name Man Suspected of Being Salah Abdeslam’s Accomplice
item.description: Najim Laachraoui was with Mr. Abdeslam, who is charged with terrorist murder over the Paris attacks, as they passed between Hungary and Austria in September.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.media:description: A fake identity card in the name of Soufiane Kayal. A man using that name rented a house in the town of Auvelais, about 33 miles south of Brussels, that was searched by the police on Nov. 26.

item.title: Congolese Politician, Jean-Pierre Bemba, Is Convicted of War Crimes
item.description: Mr. Bemba led a militia that committed rape and murder in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003, the International Criminal Court found.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Jean-Pierre Bemba, center, at the International Criminal Court on Monday in The Hague.

item.title: Boaty McBoatface: What You Get When You Let the Internet Decide
item.description: A proposal by a British agency to let the Internet name a research ship is the latest in a trend of web users having some fun with public polls.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS
item.media:description: A computer image of the research vessel, which is still being designed and is scheduled to set sail in 2019.

item.title: Letter From Europe: France Takes a Back Seat to Germany in E.U. Migrant Crisis
item.description: The French appear to be losing ground as a voice to be reckoned with in Europe.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France greeting Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany at the Élysée Palace in Paris on March 4.

item.title: A View of ISIS’s Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
item.description: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI, ALISSA J. RUBIN and LAURE FOURQUET
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated at the Bataclan concert hall during the Paris attacks in November. Investigators hope the arrest of Salah Abdeslam will shed new light on the assaults.
